newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Gloomy days seen for Pakistani stocks.
newsitem.headline: Gloomy days seen for Pakistani stocks.

text.p: Pakistani stocks, which have shed 286 points since the release of a tax-packed federal budget on June 13, are likely to be hit further in months ahead by political unrest and a troubled economy, brokers said.
The teetering Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) 100-share index will remain under pressure in the next quarter and is likely to sink below the 1,400-point support level, they said.

"The worse is not yet over, said Manochar Jamal, chief dealer of Taurus Securities. "The opposition parties' anti-government movement and a hard-pressed economy offers little attraction for local and foreign investors."

The KSE index dropped 3.42 points, or 0.24 percent, on Thursday, the last trading day before the Moslem weekend, hitting a new year-low at 1,418.57 amid a record eight-month low trading volume of 12.77 million shares.

"With local institutions hit by an acute liquidity crunch and foreign investors on the sidelines, trading volumes have gradually dwindled and hardly six or seven speculative scrips are generating activity," Jamal said.
Dealers said the inflow of foreign funds shrunk due to the rise in U.S. interest rates.
Continued depreciation of the Pakistani rupee also remains a key dampening factor for the stock market.
"For average investors, there is no sense in investing in the stock market," Mumtaz Kazmi of Global Securities said. "With the rupee's continued downslide, the dollar offers a better investment."
The rupee has fallen 1.48 percent against the dollar since July 1, the start of fiscal 1996/97 (July/June), while it lost 13.2 percent in the previous year.

Brokers say another major factor depressing Pakistani stocks is the 1996/97 budget, in which Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government imposed new taxes of 42.08 billion rupees to cut the deficit to 4.0 percent from more than 5.0 percent in 1995/96.
"New taxes have hit the private sector," dealer Ather Raouf of Carr Mashriq said. "Those who pay taxes have been burdened with more taxes bearing a negative impact on market sentiment.
"The index has continued to slip since the budget was announced while the government todate is unable to finalise its figures owing to concessions given to various interest groups."
A delay by the International Monetary Fund in disbursing its third tranche from a $600 million standby loan to Pakistan has also shaken investor confidence. Payments were due in June.
The IMF has indicated it will not review Pakistan's economic policies until Bhutto's government finalises its budget figures.
"Investors will remain in a wait-and-see mood until the fate of the IMF's standby loan is decided," one analyst said.
"A clean chit of approval to the government's financial policies by the IMF can prove a shot in the arm for the ailing Pakistani economy and revive investors' confidence."
Market analysts say investment choices among Pakistani stocks would also remain limited in the short to medium term.
Sectors which looked attractive in 1994, when the index peaked at a dizzying 2,600 points, are not exciting any more, said Farooq Lakhani of International Asset Management Co.
Financials, for example, had exhausted their growth potential, he said.

Only select fuel and energy stocks and fertiliser, communications and pharmaceutical companies will generate limited interest and a turnaround in index in early 1997 will be more on technicals rather than fundamentals, dealers said.
